clusters.title: Academic Outcomes
clusters.description: Homeschooled students outperform public school peers in standardized tests, scoring 15 to 30 percentile points higher. 87% of studies indicate better academic and social outcomes for homeschoolers. Despite a 23% lower college attendance rate, homeschooled students have a higher college acceptance rate of 87% compared to 68% for public school graduates. They also show higher involvement in community service, with 71% participation compared to 37% from public schools. However, homeschooled students have a lower high school graduation rate of 66.7% versus 91% for public school students.

22% of homeschoolers were more likely to be rural.
16% of the broader school-age population was rural.

clusters.title: Demographic Insights
clusters.description: The number of homeschooled students has seen significant growth over the years, with the U.S. witnessing a rise from 1.1 million in 2003 to 2.3 million in 2020. By 2021, homeschooling represented about 11% of school-age children in the U.S. The compound annual growth rate from 2016 to 2021 was 10.1%. Demographically, 41% of U.S. homeschoolers are from ethnic minorities, with 68% being White, 15% Hispanic, 8% Black, and 4% Asian. A majority, 92% of parents, plan for their children's full K-12 education at home. Despite this, homeschooled students are 23% less likely to attend college compared to their traditionally schooled peers.

clusters.title: Homeschool Surge
clusters.description: The number of homeschooled students in the United States has significantly increased over the years, doubling from 1.1 million in 2003 to 2.3 million in 2020. By the 2021-2022 school year, about 3.1 million students were homeschooled, with numbers reaching between 4 to 5 million during March 2021. Homeschooling has also resulted in substantial tax savings, with estimates of up to $56 billion annually, and approximately $51 billion saved in the 2021-2022 school year alone.

merged_facts.merged_content: The number of homeschooled children in the U.S. has increased over the years with notable figures from 1999 to 2024. In 2020, an estimated 2.5 million students were homeschooled in the US, around 5.2% of all school-aged children.
